utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I don’t feel good.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Oh. You don’t feel warm.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: My stomach hurts.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Honey, if you don’t have a fever –

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I don’t want to go to school, I can do my work at home.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Jessica, what’s wrong?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Everybody hates me.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Oh, they don’t hate you. They don’t even know you because they’re too ignorant to try.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I hate myself!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Jessica, don’t say that. Oh, honey, look at me, look at me. You are a wonderful, beautiful, little girl. Don’t let a few bad apples –

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: A few? Try my whole class.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Remember the story where the guy keeps saying that he hates green eggs and ham, and then at the end he realized he really loved them? One day they’re gonna realize what a great kid you really are. You’ve just gotta be like Sam I Am, and don’t give up.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Some classmate
utterance.content: Come on, Jessica, hurry!

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: My arm hurts.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: My chest hurts.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: How do you think the ground feels?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I can’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You ever see an infected pierced scrotum?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Um, no, but I know a few people on whom I’d like to see it happen. We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if pain’s what you’re after the penis is really the way to go. I’d recommend the apadravya.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We’re not talking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh? Sounded like we were.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, you’re attempting to avoid talking because you know what I want to talk about.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nipples?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You need to get rid of one of your people.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely. As soon as I do performance reviews. And then review the reviews, of course. Because a decision like this can’t be made without proper, you know, review. Shouldn’t take longer than a month, maybe two. Four at the most, unless it gets complicated.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There’s no way out on this. You may as well get it over with as fast as you can, like ripping off a band-aid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only instead of a two-cent piece of tape and gauze it’s a human being.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Like you care.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Like you don’t.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You have a week. Get it done.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We have a referral from Dr. Linkowitz.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t know him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He knows you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s the problem?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Heart attack.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Definitely don’t know him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The patient’s ten.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ten year olds do not have heart attacks. It’s gotta be a mistake.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. The simplest explanation is she’s a forty-year-old lying about her age. Maybe an actress trying to hang on.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I meant, maybe the tests were wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s what the ER thought. Three CKMBs were positive, the EKG shows classic signs of ST elevation. It’s a heart attack.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s morbidly obese. The “morbid” part of that raises alarms.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Come on, it takes decades to eat your way into a heart attack.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Doesn’t take decades to kill yourself. If I was that fat, I’d be pretty tempted to knock back a bottle of pills.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s not a drug overdose. The fatigue, muscle pain, and difficulty concentrating have been bothering her for over a year.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That’s because of her depression.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s what five pediatricians, two nutritionists, and a psychologist said. The heart attack would seem to indicate that they missed something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s got to be something genetic.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What about Metabolic Syndrome X?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Insulin resistance?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Syndrome X could cause a stroke, but I don’t know about a heart attack.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could, if her blood pressure was high enough.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Which is likely, considering her weight.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It fits the symptoms. Me likee. Do a hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp. Oh, and one more thing. I’ve been told that I’ve got to get rid of one of you guys by the end of the week. New sheriff, belt tightening, you know how it goes. Okay, carry on.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s some kind of game, House’s own version of “Punk’d”.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s not House, it’s Vogler. We can’t let it get to us, we’ve got to stick together.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What are you suggesting, we start slashing each other’s throats?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m suggesting it’s a zero-sum game. Your loss is my win. That’s not conducive to team play.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which is what House seems to want. I'm with Cameron. May be a bad strategy, but I don’t want to give House his satisfaction. Come on, sick kid, remember?

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: She’s diabetic?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, but it’s similar. MSX patients don’t respond normally to insulin, which causes her body to create too much, which causes metabolic abnormalities. We’re going to do a test to be sure, but there are certain dangers.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Is this thing treatable?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s controllable through proper diet and exercise.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Wait. Jessica already eats right. And she exercises every day!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I know you’ve already seen several nutritionists –

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: And we’ve done everything they recommended.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I understand, but –

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Why can’t any of you doctors see past her weight? If diet and exercise are the treatment, then the diagnosis is wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It might be, but the only way we’ll know is if you’ll let us do this test.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: It’s really bad, especially at night. It’s like my heart is on fire, like it’s, uh, oh, I don’t know, like it’s…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Burning?

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Exactly!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm, sounds almost like heartburn.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: So, can you give me something?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Like a thesaurus?

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I take it you never mentioned this during any of your prenatal visits.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Prenatal? I’m not pregnant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, you don’t get to make that call unless you have a stethoscope. Union rules.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: I know when I’m pregnant, all right? I have six kids. That’s why my husband had a vasectomy and we use condoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Vasectomies can reverse themselves, condoms break.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Okay. This is what a woman is supposed to look like. Okay, we’re not just skin and bones. We have flesh. We have curves.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have little people inside you. Okay, okay, I’m sorry. I guess I must have just been brainwashed by the media, and all those years of medical training.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Damn right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let’s see if I can find some antacids while the nurse gets some blood.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Blood, why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The heartburn, gotta make sure it’s not spreading.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I don’t want to.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The test involves some pretty precise measurements. If we don’t know exactly how much you weigh, we won’t get the right answers.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tell you a secret. When I was your age, I was heavy, too.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Were you over 100?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Way over. The kids in my neighborhood used to call me Rerun.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Rerun?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He was a heavy guy from TV. I used to pretend I liked it, but I didn’t.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: How come you’re not heavy any more?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ninth grade, grew five inches, everything kind of evened out.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: You think that’ll happen to me?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, yeah! I mean, your mom’s tall, and you are a little short for your age. You’ll probably spring right up.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Obesity isn’t something you just grow out of.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Take it you’ve never seen a baby?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s not a baby, she’s ten!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And you figure making her feel like crap would do her a world of good?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, if it gets her off the couch!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m sure she’s already under enough pressure.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not from mummy.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Everything in society tells us we have to be thin to be successful.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, society tells you you have to be thin to be attractive. And guess what, that’s what attractive means: that society likes looking at you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I think we should be telling our kids it’s fine as long as they’re healthy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: All right. You weigh 90 pounds because it makes you healthier?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Forget it. He’s just cranky because he's the one who's going to get the axe.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So, any thoughts?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: On what? Sharon’s plan for Gaza?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Who you’re gonna let go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m thinking I can convince Vogler it would be more cost-efficient to let me keep all of them.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, you should be able to pull that off. Most billionaires aren’t very good with numbers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It will be more cost-efficient once I’ve grabbed Cameron’s ass, called Foreman a spade, and Chase… well, I can grab his ass, too.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You are uniquely talented in many areas, but office politics is not one of them. Don’t take Vogler on.

utterance.speaker: Cashier
utterance.content: Separate or together?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Together.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Increasing glucose to 6.9 milligrams per minute.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I’m thirsty.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just a little bit longer, and you’ll be done.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Like Dr. Chase.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Wanna put some money on it?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I said I’m thirsty.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just five more minutes, okay, sweetheart?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I’m not your sweetheart, don’t call me that.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Jessica, that’s not nice.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: You’re the ones who aren’t nice.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Jessica…

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: You’re not either! I don’t want to do this anymore! [She rips off the nasal prongs to help her breathe

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Jessica! Jessica, you have to calm down!

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Let me go!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She’s gotta be getting hypoglycemic.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: What’s wrong?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hey, calm down!

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Let go of me! Get it out of me, you son of a bitch! Bastards!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s sedated. Mrs. Simms, don’t worry. Hypoglycemia can cause temporary psychosis and it’s a common complication during a HEC procedure.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: I never wanted it done in the first place.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We understand you’re upset, but –

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: You were supposed to be monitoring her condition. but instead you were bickering and placing bets.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I apologize if we weren’t paying full attention to your daughter, but I assure you that –

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Oh, please. Save your pathetic insincerity for your boyfriend.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re wrong. She is, in fact, pathetically sincere. And they didn’t screw it up.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Who are you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m from the lab. The blood tests showed your daughter wasn’t hypoglycemic, which means her psychosis wasn’t caused by anything these doctors did.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: So then what was it caused by?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have no idea, but you’ll be happy to hear it can’t be cured by diet or exercise.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What else could cause uncontrollable rage in a ten-year-old?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Nothing that could also cause a heart attack.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I assume I don’t have to point out that now would be an extremely good time for one of you to distinguish yourself with a brilliant idea.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A hypercoaguable state could cause a blood clot. Blood clots can cause a heart attack.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: More likely to cause a stroke, not the psychosis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, you’re wrong. If the clot made it to the amygdala area of the brain, it might cause uncontrollable rage.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Right, because anything’s possible, but nothing’s going to cause multiple clots in a kid this age.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s fat!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Obesity doesn’t cause blood clots.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Extremely obese patients can get a fat embolus.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Right, after they get liposuction which she’s clearly never had.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How do you know?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because we have her medical records. And because no plastic surgeon in his right mind is going to give a ten-year-old liposuction!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Have you ever met a plastic surgeon who was in their right mind?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She hasn’t had liposuction.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But what about some other ridiculous obesity treatment?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Like what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Diet pills can cause heart attacks and blood clots.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her tox screen was negative.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wouldn’t show over-the-counter weight loss drugs.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her mother wouldn’t give her diet pills.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, she thinks her daughter’s perfect just the way she is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s lying. Okay, you two, heparin and warfarin to prevent further clotting. And you, find those pills.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not diet pills. You might want to broaden the search just a little. And don’t just ask the mom, if she hasn’t mentioned yet, she’s not gonna –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If you’re gonna fire someone, go ahead and do it, but don’t treat us like lab rats, testing how long it takes us to get us at one another’s throats.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what should I do?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t give a damn what you do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, I had noticed your complete indifference. You don’t even offer a medical opinion any more. Who would you fire?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not my call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want your opinion. Fine, it’s you. Either way, you’re making a choice.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Chase.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wh- Because he screwed up an angio a month ago?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Anyone can make a mistake.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, it’s the money. You resent it, but you’re going to tell me he doesn’t need the job.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He doesn’t appreciate the job.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He was ready to go three rounds with Cameron for it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He wants the job. He just doesn’t appreciate it. There’s nothing wrong with just wanting to hang out, but this is not the place to do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m surprised.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You thought I’d pick Cameron?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I didn’t think you’d pick at all.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I guess he’s not the “rise above the fray” guy he likes to think he is.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You practically forced it out of him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s scared of losing his job, just like everyone else.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’ve been thinking. You’ve made it quite clear that you’re miserable here –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am not miserable.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re not happy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And you are?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: With… my job, yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am exactly where I want to be doing exactly what I want to do.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think I sense a hint of sarcasm there. Why don’t you pick yourself? Quit?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmmm… I was wrong.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: About Vogler or Foreman?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mrs. Hernandez’s pregnancy tests.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Who’s Mrs. Hernandez?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either a woman carrying an alien baby or your newest patient.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, you never saw her with any pills? She never mentioned anything?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Would it be all right if I talked to a couple of her friends?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, I’m not going to interrogate them, but I just want to ask if Jessica ever mentioned anything. It’s pretty important, she’s very sick.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not one?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Kids?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: What’s the status on House?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He asked for time to complete performance reviews on everyone in his department.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: And you told him no and gave him how long?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A week. He’ll do it.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Guy’s never done what he’s told. Don’t see why he’s going to start now. Hi! Edward Vogler. Is Dr. House claiming that I’m forcing him to get rid of one of you? I assume his goal is to stir up antagonism toward me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And your goal is?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I am forcing him. I’ll do whatever I can to ease the transition for whoever he chooses.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If you’re feeling guilty about your decision, there is an easy solution.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I don’t feel guilty.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Then why approach me and tell me all this?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I don’t feel guilty, that doesn’t mean I don’t feel bad. I’m rich, but I’m still human. I just wanted you to know that if there’s anything I can do for you, my door’s open.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You looking for info? Thought you already had House all figured out?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I do. Don’t know his team, though.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The ultrasound and biopsy confirmed our worry. The tumor is extremely large, at least thirty pounds.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Oh, God.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s actually a personal record for this clinic.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: But it’s completely benign, there’s no sign of cancer at all. I’ve already spoken with Dr. Bergin, and he’s available first thing in the morning.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: For what?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: For the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: But if it’s not cancer, it can’t kill me, right?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: …No.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: I’ll have a huge scar! I won’t be able to wear a bikini!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You wear a bikini now?

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Yeah, you got a problem with that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, but I’ve never gone swimming with you.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: I knew it. That’s what this is all about! You are trying to force me to have cosmetic surgery!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s exactly why I planted a thirty pound tumor on your ovary.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: It’s not gonna kill me. The only thing surgery is going to do is change the way I look. That is the definition of “cosmetic surgery”.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Uh, it would also relieve your heartburn and discomfort.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Yeah, right. Why give an antacid when you can cut someone up and make them look a little easier on your eyes? My husband loves my body. He can’t get enough of it. you think he’s gonna want to touch me if I look like I’ve been gutted like a fish?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That was unexpected.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, it was.

utterance.speaker: Clementine
utterance.content: All she does during recess is run laps around the playground. She says she’s exercising, but everyone knows it’s just because no one wants to play with her. I mean, I’m only her buddy because Ms. Ayers assigned her to me. That does not mean I am her friend.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ll make sure her doctors are all clear on that.

utterance.speaker: Clementine
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, has she ever said anything to you about diet pills?

utterance.speaker: Clementine
utterance.content: Heh, she told you that, too.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What do you mean?

utterance.speaker: Clementine
utterance.content: I totally busted her for taking drugs one day. She totally lied, said they were diet pills her mom had given her. Come on, get real. No way a girl like that is taking diet pills.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: I didn’t give her diet pills, I would never do that!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right, so it was her imaginary mom.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: She didn’t take any pills, the girl’s lying!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why would she lie?

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Because she’s another mean little jerk?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Mom.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: I’m sorry, honey.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Clemmie didn’t lie. I did. I took the pills. I told her you gave them to me ‘cause I didn’t want to get in trouble.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where did you get them?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I took them. From the store.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Why? Why would you do that?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Because I didn’t want to be ugly anymore.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Oh, baby. You’re not ugly.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Yes, I am! I know you don’t think so, but I am! I’m disgusting.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Jessica, please, don’t say that.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: I just, just wanted to fit in. You know, have friends? Or at least have one person my age be nice to me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Listen, the pills cause blood clots, heart attacks, and insomnia. It explains everything. We’ll keep her overnight to make sure, but she’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I can’t believe she was that desperate.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I’m sure that if everyone I knew hated me, I couldn’t bear to look at me. I wouldn’t go so far as to shoplift.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not talking about the shoplifting.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m sure she didn’t even know they were dangerous. She probably saw them advertised on TV or over the internet.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Right, so I guess it’s the media and pharmaceutical companies’ fault now? Not the fact that she can’t stop shoving food down her throat. No one forced her to get fat.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No one forced a cancer patient to get cancer.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Give me a break, it’s not a disease.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Have you seen the latest research?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yes, I have. What I haven’t seen lately is a kid eating an apple or riding a bike. You Americans can’t even compete with the rest of the world in basketball anymore, unless, of course, it’s the type you play with a remote control on a big screen TV.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wait! Are you going to let him say that? He insulted our basketball teams!

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Oh, my God!! Mommy, they hurt so bad!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Please help me!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: She’s bleeding!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: From where?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Oh, my god! Just please stop it, please!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Diet pills don’t cause skin necrosis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Could be something related to the pills.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Or not.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or both. Diet pills brought her to us, we gave her the sores.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You think she got a staph infection from something here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not saying the hospital gave the sores, I’m saying we did. By treating her. Warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Highly unlikely. We started her on heparin before the warfarin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who gave her the heparin?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I gave warfarin, she gave heparin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure you didn’t both give her warfarin?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yes, I did not screw up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you actually see her prepare and administer the heparin? Enough said.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You were standing right there.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I was preparing my own dose.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, right. There’s gotta be some other cause.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: None that I can think of. Let’s fix the mistake. Give her unfractionated IV heparin and low molecular weight heparin by subcutaneous injection stat.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Making me look bad is not going to save your job.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You think you’re incapable of making a mistake?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You think that I am that weak that I am just going to roll over and take this?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: House isn’t just going to protect you because you kiss his ass!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Vogler wants to know what he can do for me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey! Stop worrying about your asses and start worrying about the patient’s.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: She sleeping?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: As a result of the sedatives, yeah. Can’t let her wake up, too much pain.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: “Warfarin-induced skin necrosis”. I have no idea what that means. But it says here we gave her the warfarin, and I do know what “induced” means… we did this?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: At this point it’s not exactly clear. You know, I should probably talk to Dr. House.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Oh, you two need time to get your story straight.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He doesn’t tell me what to do.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: So you don’t just blindly follow his commands. You’re your own man. And yet, here you are working for a man you can’t stand.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I respect him.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: What exactly is it you respect? His attitude toward humanity? He thinks we’re all idiots and liars. How ‘bout his attitude toward you, plays with you like a cat with a ball of string –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What do you want?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I want to know if you want to keep your job.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If he chooses to let me go, I can live with that.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: That’s not an answer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You offering to protect me?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Still not an answer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I want my job.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Dr. Chase.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Boss. What was that about?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wanted to know what warfarin is. I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Brrrr. Icy. Definitely think twice before correcting one of your mistakes again.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Correct all you want. Of course, it’s a bit more productive if there’s an actual mistake.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, I always forget that part.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I gave her the heparin, which means the necrosis is not a reaction to the warfarin, which is probably why she’s not responding to your treatment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yet. If you didn’t screw up, then what is it? You don’t have an answer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When you come up with something, let me know. I’ll be in the clinic, warming up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m the only one who’s always stood behind you when you’ve screwed up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why? Why would you support someone who screws up?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because I’m not insanely insecure. And because I can actually trust in another human being and I am not an angry, misanthropic son of a bitch.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m sorry, you said you weren’t angry. Who would you fire?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not an option.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If everyone took a pay cut and put in a few more hours we could all stay for the same amount of money.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Figures you’d try and come up with a solution where no one gets hurt. The problem is, the world doesn’t work that way just ‘cause you want it to.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Figures you’d stall and refuse to deal with the issue. Problem is, the world doesn’t go away just because you want it to.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh, he’s not in today.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s also got a bit of a drug problem. Sometimes doesn’t show up for weeks.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The MRIs are rented, but… Did you make a decision?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: He’s not gonna fire anybody.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. I’m going to cut the pay of all four of us. 17% across the board will allow you to keep us all for the same amount of money. I believe it’s what you suits call “win-win”.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: All right, if you can –

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If he can work it so we can keep the current staff for the same amount of money, what difference does it make?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not about the money.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: This is not a negotiation, it never was. I need to know that whatever I ask you to do, no matter how distasteful you find it, you’ll do it. And just as importantly, you need to know that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Even if I was Dr. House, physician-patient confidentiality protects me from annoying conversations.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah? She also tell you why she’s refusing to have it removed?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want her to regain the weight?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, tell her that and leave me alone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The tumor is benign, nothing’s gonna happen. Except maybe some more heartburn.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know where to find us. Building’s not going anywhere.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, way to win me over.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have kids! How novel! That changes everything. So if Mommy has heartburn, one of them might catch on fire.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They are cute. Have her come back in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your plight has moved me. Tell your wife to come back.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her necrosis is getting worse.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe because we’re treating her for the wrong thing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have you found the right thing?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then we continue the treatment. Hope it’s just taking longer than it should.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: At this point it doesn’t matter what caused the necrosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or who.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If we don’t stop it from spreading it will kill her before the end of the day.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What else can we do?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Get rid of it. Remove the dying flesh before it penetrates the abdominal wall.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s still a chance that the heparin treatment could start to take effect.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We’re gonna wait as long as we can, but if there’s no change in the next few hours, we’re gonna have to treat the symptoms directly.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: So you can get rid of the sores.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Through surgery. Technically, it’s an amputation.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Amputation? But the sores are –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Warfarin-induced necrosis attacks fatty tissue, mainly in the breasts.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Wait, are you talking about cutting off my daughter’s breasts? She’s ten years old!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: A radical mastectomy may be her only chance of survival.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m sorry, but I’m gonna have to ask you to sign this.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Can we talk?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What, no roses, no chocolates? If you’re here to apologize –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not here to apologize.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh-oh, that means you’re here for something more complicated.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you want to fire me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. I was just waiting for an excuse. Thank God Vogler came along. Phew!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s the only reason I can think of that you’re insisting that I made a mistake.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? Because there is another explanation. Perhaps not as much fun as your Freudian analysis, but maybe you actually made a mistake.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re doing this because you can’t deal with your feelings for me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I believe that you are the only one to express feelings. And if we’re going to look at this from a first-year psych point-of-view, maybe you want me to fire you. Maybe that’s why you’re acting weird. You –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re the one being different! You’re always pushing things, pushing the rules, pushing us, but not this time. You just jumped on this idea like a life raft. Not one question about what else it could be, no riding us for other answers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have the answer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Then why aren’t you watching TV? Or playing your damn Game Boy, or whatever else you have fun doing by yourself? Maybe I should just quit. Make it easy for everyone.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maybe you should.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Men are pigs.

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: You call me in to tell me –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I should have realized the vasectomy and condoms was overkill, but this was too obvious. Cute kids. Love her green eyes. And his baby blues. Of course, since you and your husband have brown eyes…

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Where’d you get that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: From the father of three, maximum four of your six children. So I’m thinking maybe the reason you don’t want surgery is, while your husband may find you attractive no matter what, all the other men you’re sleeping with might not be so open-minded. Which brings me back to my original thesis: men are pigs. You got nothing to worry about. You know, pretty much have sex with anyone, fat, skinny, married, single, complete strangers, relatives –

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: You? You’re sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So are you. I’m sure there are websites full of men looking for married women with surgical scars. So have the surgery. Please?

utterance.speaker: Lucille
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why have you been talking to Cameron?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Well, if House picks you I’ll be needing a new source in that room.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If he picks me?

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Sure. Foreman’s smarter, House has got a thing for Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ve been feeding you information so you’ll protect me.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: I will protect you as long as I need you. And you will feed me information as long as you need me. I spoke with Cameron because if I have alternatives, I don’t need you.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s not gonna rat on House.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Foreman ever said anything about talking to me? Interesting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s been almost three hours, still no change in her condition.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I think we should get her into surgery.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So what do you want to do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Assume that Cameron didn’t screw up. What if it’s not the warfarin?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It has to be. The sores presented right after we –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, right, right, but let’s just say it’s not. Come on, come on, what have you got?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Can I have a second to think?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, there’s no time to think! Say the first thing that comes to you head.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s fat.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Enough already, okay? We’ve got it, you hate fat people.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That’s not what I meant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We already considered obesity as a cause.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So did all her other doctors.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, what if it’s not a cause? What if it’s a symptom?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, so what could cause obesity and skin necrosis? Listen, I don’t care if it makes sense, just give me something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ulcers secondary to vaculitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, that’s just sores, not obesity.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pyoderma gangrenosum?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: More sores. Okay, let’s look at it from the other side. What has obesity as a symptom?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hypothyroidism?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Genetics are more likely. Her mom’s heavy, too.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s not just heavy. She’s tall. We have any history on the dad?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah. 6’1”.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kid’s short. We’ve got stunted growth, high blood pressure, blood clots, obesity – it’s Cushing’s.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, necrosis doesn’t present in –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In rare cases Cushing’s can cause hypercalcemia, which can lead to the same skin necrosis as warfarin. It’s perfect. It explains everyting.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Except it’s not Cushing’s. She’s had multiple blood tests and none show abnormal cortisol levels.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The hypercortisolism could be cyclical, we just didn’t catch it in the right phase.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll have to do another UFC.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s no time! We’ve got less than an hour to make the call.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If we treat for Cushing’s and we’re wrong, she’s dead.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If we assume it’s not Cushing’s, she’ll lose her breasts and may still be sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do an MRI.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You want us to look for hypercortisolism with an MRI?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I want you to look for what could cause hypercortisolism with an MRI.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Nothing on the adrenals. Heard Cameron went home, she sick?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Go back to the pituitary views. She seemed okay.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Think she’s got another reason for leaving?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I hope so. Wait, stop. There. What’s that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A tumor.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s Cushing’s.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The tumor causes Cushing’s. Cushing’s messes with hormone production. Hormones control everything: growth, weight –

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Can you fix it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’ll need surgery to remove the tumor. Once it’s gone, everything will get normal very fast.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: No mastectomy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Thank God.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The surgery’s dangerous. The pituitary is located between the caverns of the sinuses, basically right between the eyes. The area contains the nerves that control eye movement and the major arteries that feed the brain.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Oh, my God.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your surgeon will approach the gland transphenoidally. An incision will be made under the lip in which he’ll insert a fiberoptic microscope. Once the tumor’s found, he’ll cut it into small pieces and remove it from the same hole under the lip. The whole procedure should take about three hours and your daughter should be able to go home in a few days. The sores will go away, as well as her fatigue and her muscle pain. She’ll even start losing weight.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Jessica.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Is that really you?

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s me.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You look fantastic!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: She always looked fantastic.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s been a week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, it’s over a week. Where have you guys been?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Who is it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: No, Chase stays. Pick someone else.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The deal was –

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Deal’s changed. Pick someone else.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Vogler
utterance.content: Pick someone else or it’ll be the whole department.
